title: NGrainy
author: NGrainy
content: I use the test fixture to check the S17+, it shows error asic, and there is more than one. Do all of the chips shown need to be replaced? comments.author: BitMaxz
comments.body: Quote from: NGrainy on August 09, 2022, 05:49:56 AMI use the test fixture to check the S17+, it shows error asic, and there is more than one. Do all of the chips shown need to be replaced? Or is it just one chip failure that affects other chips?I suggest you check them one by one chips that you see some errors if you don't know how to locate and test them there is a guide on ZeusBTC that will help troubleshoot and repair the whole  s17+ hashboard. You can follow the guide from this link "Antminer s17 plus Hashboard Repair Guide" Or download the repair guide here https://www.zeusbtc.com/articles/information/182-antminer-s17-manual-download

comments.author: philipma1957
comments.body: S17+ boards are known to be hard to repair good luck.

comments.author: GFDhd
comments.body: My insight is to use a programmer to rewrite the contents of the EEPROM first, then solder the chip again, and if the problem still persists, the faulty ASIC chip needs to be replaced.

comments.author: mikeywith
comments.body: I can't really understand the logs you posted, but to answer your question, one bad chip can stop the whole board from working, and usually or most often I might say, it's one bad chip that needs repair, using the text fixture alone isn't enough, you will need to measure the voltage on each chip, you may also visually inspect the chips and look for solder balls that are shorting a chip or two.

comments.author: Rodemi
comments.body: You may need to re-solder all the chips that show the failure, because the 17 series miners use the low-temperature tin for soldering, so many chips have the problem of virtual soldering. In many cases, you only need to re-solder them to solve the problem. If it still doesn't work, you may need to replace the chip. If the number of chips that need to be replaced is large, it is obviously not cost-effective.

comments.author: MinerMEDIC
comments.body: Given the age of these Hashboards and their poor design, that is a good hashboard. You go mucking about with that just to get a few more cores and you’re gonna find yourself with zero ASIC very quickly.
